sourceDesc.p: Digitized using Transkribus. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via taxonomy.xml.

prefixDef.p: URIs using the eats prefix are references to EATS entities.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.
Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.

div.head: f 252v
div.ab: Ordo paginarum ludi Corporis Christi tempore Willelmi Alne Maioris Anno regni Regis Henrici quinti post conquestum Anglie tercio °compilatus per Rogerum Burton clericum communem in anno domini millesimo ccccxvmo

cell.note: °Deliuerande Sunt Sedule Paginarum subsequenter in forma subscripta . artificiis Per vj. Seruientes Maioris ad clauam prima vel ija. septimana xlma. Annuatim scribende per Communem Clericum°

row.cell:
Deus pater omnipotens creans & formans celos Angelos & archangelos
luciferum & angelos qui cum eo ceciderunt in infernumDeus... infernum: over erasure

Deus pater in sua substancia creans terramterram: over erasure & omnia que in eaea: over erasure
sunt per spacium v dierumv dierum: over erasure

Deus pater formans Adam de lymo terre & faciens Euam de costa Ade &
inspirans eos spiritude... spiritu: partly over erasure vite
Deus prohibens Adam & Euam ne comederent de ligno vite
Adam & Eua & arbor inter eos serpens decipiens eos cum pomis Deus loquens eis & maledicens serpentem & angelusangelus: erasure follows cum gladio eiciens eos de paradiso
Adam & Eua Angelus cum vanga & colo assignans eis laborem
Deus premuniens Noe facere archam de lignis leuigatis
Noe in Arche & vxor eius tres filij Noe cum vxoribus suis cum diuersis animalibus
Abraham immolans filium suum °Isaac° super altare garcio cum bosco & angelus

Moyses exaltans serpentem in : deserto Pharao. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "deserto Pharao" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Moyſes exalting the ſerpent in the wilderneſs, king Pharao, eight Jews, admiring and expecting." See Endnote. Rex viij Iudei admirantes : et expectantes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "et expectantes" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Moyſes exalting the ſerpent in the wilderneſs, king Pharao, eight Jews, admiring and expecting." See Endnote.

°doctor declarans dicta prophetarum de nativitate Christi futura°
°Maria°
Angelus salutans eam Maria salutans Elizabeth

°Maria° °Iosep volens : dimittere. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "dimittere" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Mary, Joſeph willing to put her away, an angel ſpeaking to them that they ſhould go to Bedlem." See Endnote. eam : angelus eis loquens. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "angelus eis loquens" in the damaged area here; compare to the repetition of this entry immediately below. Smith adds that "eis loquens" are "written over an erased line." Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Mary, Joſeph willing to put her away, an angel ſpeaking to them that they ſhould go to Bedlem." See Endnote. vt transeant
vsque Bedlem°

°Maria Iosep volens occult e dimettere eam. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 gives "e dimettere eam"; Stevens/Dorrell 1974 give "e dimittere eam," noting that this entry, an imperfect repetition of the entry prior, is "[a]t bottom of folio in another hand and blotted against fol. 253r" and so "not noted by Smith." See Endnote. angelus eis loquens ut
transeant vsque bethleem°

Maria cum
Ioseph . obstetrix / puer natus °iacens in presepio°°iacens in
presepio°: over erasure inter bouen & azinum & angelus loquens
°pastoribus°°pastoribus°: over erasure & ludentibus in pagina sequente /
Pastores loquentes adinuicem °stella in oriente° / Angelus nuncians °pastoribus gaudium de puero nato°

Tres Reges venientes ab oriente / herodes interogans eos de puero Iesu
°& filius herodis° & duo consi°liarij & nuncius /./.° Maria cum puero
& stella desuper & tres Reges offerentes munera

°quadam°for quondam. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 reads this insertion as "quadam" but adds "for quondam" in the note; Stevens/Dorrell 1974 simply transcribe as "quandam," "added in another hand above Domus; iam Masons in another hand after Leonardi." Domus sancti
leonardi
°iam Masons°

Maria cum puero Iosep Anna obstetrix cum pullis columbarum
Symeon recipiens puerum in vlnas suas & duo filij Symeonis
Maria cum puero & Iosep fugientes in Egiptum Angelo nunciante

Herodes preci : -piens pueros occidi iiij-. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "-piens pueros occidi iiij-" in the damaged area here, though Stevens and Dorrell put the particles "-piens" and "iiij-" outside of the square brackets they use to mark the otherwise unreadable text that they have drawn from prior transcriptions. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Herod commanding the children to be ſlain; four ſoldiers with lances, two councellors of the king, and ſour women lamenting the ſlaughter of them." See Endnote.or milites cum lanceis duo : consiliarii Regis et. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "consiliarii Regis et" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Herod commanding the children to be ſlain; four ſoldiers with lances, two councellors of the king, and ſour women lamenting the ſlaughter of them." See Endnote.
iiij mulieres deflentes : occisionem puerorum suorum. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "occisionem puerorum suorum" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Herod commanding the children to be ſlain; four ſoldiers with lances, two councellors of the king, and ſour women lamenting the ſlaughter of them." See Endnote.

Iesus °Doctores puer° sedens : in templo in medio. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "in templo in medio" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "The doctors, the child Jeſus ſitting in the temple in the midſt of the, hearing them and aſking them queſtions. Four Jews, Mary, and Joſeph ſeeking him and ſinding him in the temple." See Endnote. eorum interrogans eos & respondens : eis iiijor Judei Maria et Josep. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "eis iiijor Judei Maria et Josep" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "The doctors, the child Jeſus ſitting in the temple in the midſt of the, hearing them and aſking them queſtions. Four Jews, Mary, and Joſeph ſeeking him and ſinding him in the temple." See Endnote. querentes eum & inuen: -ientes in templo. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "-ientes in templo" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "The doctors, the child Jeſus ſitting in the temple in the midſt of the, hearing them and aſking them queſtions. Four Jews, Mary, and Joſeph ſeeking him and ſinding him in the temple." See Endnote.

Iesus Iohannes : Baptista baptizans eum et ij. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "Baptista baptizans eum et ij" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, John the baptiſt baptizing him, and two angels helping them." See Endnote. angeli : administrantes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "administrantes" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, John the baptiſt baptizing him, and two angels helping them." See Endnote.

Iesus Maria : sponsus cum sponsa Architri-. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "sponsus cum sponsa Architri-" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, Mary, bridegroom and bride, maſter of the houſhold with his family with ſix water-pots, where water is turned into wine." See Endnote.clinus cum fam: -ulia sua cum vj ydreis aque vbi. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "-ulia sua cum vj ydreis aque vbi" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, Mary, bridegroom and bride, maſter of the houſhold with his family with ſix water-pots, where water is turned into wine." See Endnote. vertitur : aqua in vinum. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "aqua in vinum" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, Mary, bridegroom and bride, maſter of the houſhold with his family with ſix water-pots, where water is turned into wine." See Endnote.

°Smythes°
ffeuersYork Prototype added note, Sergi 2024: The 1979 edition marks the Vintners', Smiths'/Fevers', and Curriers' entries with B, A, and C, respectively, assumedly to draw attention to the mismatch between this document and the York Register regarding the order of these plays.

Iesus : super Pynaculum templi et diabolus. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "super Pynaculum templi et diabolus" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus upon the pinnacle of the temple; Satan tempting with ſtones; two angels adminiſtring, &c." See Endnote. temptans eum : cum lapidibus et ij angeli administrantes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "super Pynaculum templi et diabolus &c" in the damaged area here, though REED 1979 leaves off the "&c". Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus upon the pinnacle of the temple; Satan tempting with ſtones; two angels adminiſtring, &c." See Endnote.

Petrus Iacobus & Iohannes Iesus ascendens in montem & transfiguransPetrus... & transfigurans: over erasure : se ante eos Moyses et Elyas. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "cum lapidibus et ij angeli administrantes &c" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Peter, James and John, Jeſus aſcending into the mountain and transfiguring himſelf before them. Moyſes and Elyas appearing, and a voice ſpeaking from a cloud." See Endnote. apparentes et : vox loquentis in nube. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "vox loquentis in nube" in the damaged area here, with REED 1979 noting that "loquens," not "loquentis," should be required here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Peter, James and John, Jeſus aſcending into the mountain and transfiguring himſelf before them. Moyſes and Elyas appearing, and a voice ſpeaking from a cloud." See Endnote.

°Iesus° Simon : leprosus rogans Jesu vt manducaret cum eo. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "leprosus rogans Jesu vt manducaret cum eo" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Simon the leper aſking Jeſus if he would eat with him. Two diſciples, Mary Magdalene waſhing the feet of Jeſus, and wiping them with her hair." See Endnote. ij discipuli Maria Magdalena : lauans pedes Jesu. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "Maria Magdalena lauans pedes Jesu" in the damaged area here, though REED 1979 does not include the words "Maria Magdalena" in the notes that mark the otherwise unreadable text drawn from prior transcriptions. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Simon the leper aſking Jeſus if he would eat with him. Two diſciples, Mary Magdalene waſhing the feet of Jeſus, and wiping them with her hair." See Endnote. lacrimis : suis et capillis suis tergens. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "suis et capillis suis tergens" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Simon the leper aſking Jeſus if he would eat with him. Two diſciples, Mary Magdalene waſhing the feet of Jeſus, and wiping them with her hair." See Endnote.

Iesus : duo apostoli. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "duo apostoli" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, two apoſtles, the woman taken in adultery, four Jews accuſing her." See Endnote. mulier deprehensa in adulterio iiijor Iudei accusantes eam
Iesus iiijor apostoli lazarus in sepulcro Maria Magdalena & Martha & ij Iudei admirantes

Iesus super asinum cum pullo suo xij ij apostoli sequentes Iesum sex diuites & sex pauperes viij pueri cum ramis palmarum cantantes Benedictus &c. & Zacheus ascendens in aborem sicamorumascendens... sicamorum: over erasure
Pylatus Cayphas duo Milites °tres Iudei° °&° Iudas vendens Iesum

agnus paschalis Cena Domini: xij apostoli Iesus pre cinctus lintheo lauans pedes eorum agnus paschalis institucio sacramenti corporis christi in noua lege Communio apostolorumerasure between this line and following pageant

Pilatus Cayphas Annas xiiij Milites armati Malcus °Iesu° Petrus Iacobus Iohannes °Iesus° & Iudas ns: osculans. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "osculans" in the damaged area here, though REED 1979 finds the final "-ns" readable in the original. The Drake 1736 translation gives "kiſſing." See Endnote. °Iesum° & tradens eum

nas: Annas. 2025 expanded note: Smith 1885 reads "Jesus Anna Cayphas" here, all of which Stevens/Dorrell 1974 mark as otherwise unreadable; in contrast, REED 1979 does not read the word "Jesus" at all here, while presenting "Cayphas", and the "-nas" of "Annas", as readable in the extant Ordo. The Drake 1736 translation gives "Je#x017F;us, Annas, Cayphas". See Endnote. Cayphas et iiijor Iudei percucientes et colantes: colaphizantes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "colaphizantes." Smith 1885 does not mark the preceding "et" in any way, though REED 1979 marks it as cancelled and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 marks it as unreadable. The Drake 1736 translation gives, surprisingly, "baſtinadoing". See Endnote. °Iesum Petrus Mulier accusans Petrum & Malchus°

cell.note: : Tapisers. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Tapisers." The Drake 1736 translation gives the same. See Endnote.
: Couchers. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Couchers." The Drake 1736 translation gives the same. See Endnote.

row.cell: : Jesus. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Jesus," though Stevens/Dorrell spell it as "Iesus." The Drake 1736 translation gives "Jeſus". See Endnote. Pilatus Annas Cayphas duo consiliarij & iiijor Iudei accusantes Iesum

cell.note: : Littesters. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Littesters." The Drake 1736 translation gives the same. See Endnote.

row.cell: : Herodes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Herodes." The Drake 1736 translation gives "Herod". See Endnote. duo consiliarii: 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 notes that "-liarii" is written "over erasure" and does not mark it as otherwise unreadable. However, Stevens/Dorrell 1974 mark "duo consiliarii" as otherwise unreadable, accept Smith 1885's reading of the same. The Drake 1736 translation gives "two councellors". See Endnote. iiijor milites Iesus & iij Iudei

: Cukes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Cukes." The Drake 1736 translation gives the same. See Endnote.
Waterleders

: Pilatus. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Pilatus." The Drake 1736 translation gives "Pylat". See Endnote. Anna Cayphas duo Iudei & Iudas ans: reportans. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "reportans." The Drake 1736 translation gives "carrying". See Endnote. eis xxx argenteos

cell.note: : Tielmakers. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Tielmakers." The Drake 1736 translation gives "Tiel-makers". However, REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 differ significantly from both Smith 1885 and Drake 1736 regarding which other guilds are assigned to this entry, assumedly based on differing readings of the alignment of the left-hand Ordo column on this very damaged leaf. REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 assign this entry only to the "Tielmakers," the "Milners," and to the "Ropers" and Serveourz" added in another hand. Smith 1885 and Drake 1736 include all of those guilds, but they also include the "Turners", "Hayresters", and "Bollers." Stevens/Dorrell 1974 assigns those final three guilds instead to the entry following (as does the REED 1979 English translation, here printed below). Since Smith generally disagrees with Drake, her alignment with his reading here is notable; Stevens/Dorrell 1974 do not list this change among their minor corrections to Smith's edition. Also notably, in the more concise list of guild assignments that follows the Ordo (below), the Turners and Bollers are assigned to the Scourging and Crowning with Thorns (the Hairesters are left out of that list entirely), material which has been absorbed into the Tilemakers' (et al) Ordo entry, which adds some support to Smith and Drake's reading here. See Endnote.

row.cell: °Iesus° s: Pilatus. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Pilatus," though Stevens/Dorrell 1974 does not mark it as otherwise unreadable in the extant Ordo. The Drake 1736 translation gives "Pilat". See Endnote. Cayphas Anna sex milites tenentes hastas cum vexillis & alij quattuor ducentes Iesum ab herode petentes Baraban dimitti & Iesum crucifigi & ibidem ligantes & flagellantes eum ponentes coronam spineam super caput eius tres milites mittentes sortem supper vestem Iesutres... Iesu: over erasure

cell.note: York Prototype added note, Sergi 2024: The York 1979 translation identifies these five lines as "Turners", "Hayresters", "Bollers", "Shearmen", "Toundours" (another word for Shearmen). All but the Hairesters are corroborated in the second list of guild assignments below. 2025 added note: See the footnote immediately prior, on variable readings of these guild assignments.

row.cell: I: Iesus. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Iesus," though Stevens/Dorrell 1974 does not mark it as otherwise unreadable in the extant Ordo. The Drake 1736 translation gives "Pilat". See Endnote. sanguine cruentatus portans crucem versus Caluariam Symon Sereneus / Iudei anges: angariantes. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "angariantes," though Stevens/Dorrell 1974 does not mark it as otherwise unreadable in the extant Ordo. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 leaves the word out entirely, along with most of this lengthy entry, giving the full Ordo entry only as "Jeſus covered with blood bearing his croſs towards mount Calvery, Simon Sereneus, &c." See Endnote. eum vt tolleret crucem maria mater Iesum Iohannes apostolus intimans tunc prime dampnacionem & transitum filii sui °ad Caluariam° Veronica tergens sanguinem & sudorem . de facie Iesu cum flammeolo in quo imprimitur facies Iesu & alie mulieres lamentantes Iesum

°Crux°whole line erased at top of page Iesus extensus in eaea: over erasure super terram / iiijor Iudei flagellantes & trahentes eum cum funibus et postea exaltantes crucem & corpus Iesu cruci conclauatum super montem caluarieet postea... caluarie: over erasure

Crux duo latrones crucifixi: Iesus suspensus in cruce inter eos Maria mater Iesu Iohannes Maria Iacobi & Salome longeusCrux... longeus: over erasure longeus cum lancea seruus cum spongea Pilatus Anna Cayphas Centurio Ioseph °ab Aramathia° & Nichodemus deponentes mortem Iesu °eum° & ponentes eum in sepulcro
Iesus spolians infernum xij spiritus boni et vj mali

°Centurio declarans Pilato Cayphe & Anne ° cum alijs Iudeis ° signa apparencia in mortem Iesu ° Iesus resurgens de sepulcro quatuor milites armati & tres marie lamentantes Pilatus Cayphas & Anna °Iuuenis sedens ad sepulcrum indutus albo loquens mulieribustwo later hands in this entry
Iesus °lucas & Cleophas in forma peregrinorum°°lucas...peregrinorum°: over erasure

Iesus Petrus Iohannes : Jacobus. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Jacobus". The Drake 1736 translation gives "James". See Endnote. Phillipus & alij Apostoli cum parte piscis assi & fauo : mellis et. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged text as "mellis et". Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 leaves the word out entirely, along with most of this entry, giving the full Ordo entry only as "Jeſus, Peter, John, James, Philip and other apoſles; Thomas feeling the wounds of Jeſus." See Endnote. Thomas apostolusapostolus: over erasure palpans vulnera Iesu

cell.note: : Taillyoures. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "Taillyoures." The Drake 1736 translation gives the same. See Endnote.

row.cell: Maria Iohannes Euangelista xj apostoli ij angeli Iesus ascendens coram eis & iiijor angeli portantes nubem
Maria duo angeli xj apostoli & spiritus sanctus descendens super eos & iiijor Iudei admirantes

Iesus Maria Gabriell cum ij angelis duo virgines & tres Iudei de : cognacione Marie. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "cognacione Marie" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, Mary, Gabriel with two angels, two virgins and three Jews of the kindred of Mary; eight apoſtles and two devils." See Endnote. viij apostoli & ij diaboli

QuatuorQuatuor: over erasure Apostoli : portantes feretrum. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "portantes feretrum" in the damaged area here. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Jeſus, Mary, Gabriel with two angels, two virgins and three Jews of the kindred of Mary; eight apoſtles and two devils." See Endnote. Marie et fergus pendens super feretrum is: cum ij aliis. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 gives "sum ij aliis" here, but "sum" is likely an error: Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "cum ij aliis" in the damaged area here. Drake's 1736 translation of this entry also supports the latter reading: "Four apoſtles bearing the ſhrine of Mary, Fergus hanging upon it with two other Jews and one angel." See Endnote. Iudeis °cum vno Angelo°
Maria ascendens cum turba angelorum viij apostoli & Thomas de India apostolus predicans in deserto ././

°Maria° Iesus coronans eam rum: cum turba angelorum. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of "cum turba angelorum" in the damaged area here, though Stevens/Dorrell 1974 does not include "angelorum" as an otherwise unreadable word. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Mary, and Jeſus crowning of her with a great number of angels." See Endnote. cantan: cantans. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979, Stevens/Dorrell 1974, and Smith 1885 read this word as "cantans": REED 1979 notes that there is slight damage to the end of the word, while Stevens/Dorrell 1974 does not mark it as damaged or otherwise unreadable. Drake's "very incorrect translated copy" from 1736 leaves out the word: it reads, for this full Ordo entry, "Mary, and Jeſus crowning of her with a great number of angels." See Endnote.
Iesus Maria xij apostoli iiijor angeli cum tubis & iiijor cum corona lancea & ij flagellis iiijor spiritus boni & iiijor spiritus maligni & vj diaboli

Et lviij ciues ciuitatis
habuerunt torcheas similiter
die corporis christi

div.ab:
Ordinatum est quod Portours Coblers eant antea primo
Et tunc a dexteris Websterseruauntz & Cordwaners
Et ex opposito ffullers cuttellers Girdellers Chaloners Carpenters Taillours Et tunc boni ciues et postea xxiiij xij Maior & iiijor torchee Magistri Thome de Bukton
Proclamacio ludi corporis christi facienda in vigilia corporis christi.

ab.foreign:
Oiez &c. We comand of þe kynges be halue and þe Mair & þe shirefs of þis Citee þat no man go armed in þis Citee with swerdes ne with carlill axes ne none othir defences in distourbaunce of þe kynges pees & þe play or hynderyng of þe processioun of Corpore christi and þat þai leue þare hernas in þare Ines saufand knyghtes and sqwyers of wirship þat awe haue swerdes borne eftir þame of payne of forfaiture of þaire Wapen & inprisonment of þaire bodys and þat men þat brynges furth pacentes þat þai play at the places þat is assigned þerfore and nowere elles of þe payne of forfaiture to be raysed þat is ordayned : þerfore. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Smith 1885's reading of this damaged word as "yerfore," adjusting to "Þerfore" because Smith's version of the Proclamation normalizes all "Þ" to "y" except one (see note below). Drake 1736, which presents this proclamation in Middle English, gives the same. See Endnote. °yatyat: under patch ys to say xl s° And þat men of craftes & all othir men þat fyndes torches þat þai com furth in array & in þe manere as it : has been used. 2025 expanded note: Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accepts Smith 1885's reading of this damaged text as "has been vsed"; REED 1979 reads the final word as "used," as does Drake 1736, which presents this proclamation in Middle English. See Endnote. & customed be fore þis tyme noght haueyng wapen pers: careynge tapers (Toulmin Smith, xxxiv); saveyin keepers (Drake, xxxij). 2025 expanded note: This damaged area is read quite differently by Smith 1885 ("careynge tapers") and by Drake 1736 ("saveyin keepers"). Smith's reading makes reasonable, if awkward, sense: the weaponless torch-bearers carry tapers (keeping in mind that Middle English "torch" could also refer to "candle," MED s.v. "torch, n."). However, Drake's seems superior, leading more sensibly into the subsequent phrase: no one is permitted to bear weapons except the keepers (guards) of the pageants and the officers that are keepers of the peace. Both Stevens/Dorrell 1974 and REED 1979 provide both readings. See Endnote. of þe pagentz and officers þat ar kepers : of þe pees. 2025 expanded note: Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accepts Smith 1885's reading of this damaged text as "of Þe pees"; notably, this phrase contains is the only "Þ" that Smith does not normalize to "y". Drake 1736, which presents this proclamation in Middle English, gives "of ye pees". See Endnote. of payne of forfaiture of þaire
fraunchis and þaire bodyes to prison And ‸ yat °all maner of craftmens þatSee Twycross, Meg. "Forget the 4:30am Start: Recovering a Palimpsest in the York Ordo paginarum". Medieval English Theatre 25 (2003), 98-152.
bringeth furthe ther pageantez in order & course by good players well arayed & openly spekyng vpon payn of lesyng of C s to be paid to the chambre withoute any pardon And that euery player that shall play be redy in his pagiaunt at convenyant tyme that is to say at the mydhowre betwix iiijth & vth of the cloke in the mornyng & then all oyer pageantesgo fast folowyngSee Twycross 2003 ilkon after oyer as yer course is without Tarieng sub pena facienda camere vj s viij d°York Prototype added note, Sergi 2024: And ‸ yat °all maner... vj s viij d: Meg Twycross, in "Forget the 4:30am Start: Recovering a Palimpsest in the York Ordo paginarum" in Medieval English Theatre 25 (2003), 98-152, reconstructs the original entry that this lengthy insertion (which she dates "to 1511-1519, or at the earliest 1507") replaces, using UV technology. According to Twycross, the original text here read "And þat ylk a player þat shal play þat he be redy in his pagent at able tyme of payne of inprisonment & þe forfaiture to be raysed þat is ordand þer fore". Twycross transcribes the replacement text slightly differently from the 1979 REED entry transcribed here.

row.cell: Inuentio christi in templo inter doctores

lauacio pedum ap: apostolorum under patch. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 follow Davies 1843's reading of this word as "apostolorum"; REED 1979 points out that the word is under a patch. See Endnote.

Capcio christi orantis in : Monte under patch. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 follows Davies 1843's reading of this word as "Monte", pointing out that the word is under a patch; Stevens/Dorrell 1974 gives "Monet." See Endnote.

Illusio °perryng° christi coram Ca: Caypha under patch. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 follow Davies 1843's reading of this word as "Caypha"; REED 1979 points out that the word is under a patch. See Endnote.

Accusacio °accunsyng° christi coram P: Pilato under patch. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 follow Davies 1843's reading of this word as "Pilato"; REED 1979 points out that the word is under a patch. See Endnote.

Apparicio christi Marie Magdal: Magdalene. 2025 expanded note: REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 accept Davies 1843's reading of this damaged word as "Magdalene". All three also provide "peregrinis" in the line following, but only Stevens/Dorrell 1974 notates that word as otherwise unreadable. See Endnote.

Willelmus Selby pro anima
magistri Thome Bukton

div.head: ff 252v-5
div.ab:
The order of the pageants of the play of Corpus Christi at the time of William Alne, mayor, in the third year of the reign of King Henry the Fifth, after the conquest of England. °Compiled in the year of our Lord 1415 by Roger Burton, common clerk, (who) had it registered.°
Tanners°The billets of pageants must be delivered in succession in the subscribed form to the craftsmen by six sergeants-at-arms of the mayor in the first or second week of Lent, yearly, (and) are to be written by the common clerk.° God, the almighty Father, creating and forming the heavens, the angels and archangels, Lucifer and the angels who fell with him into hell
Plasterers God the Father in his (own) substance creating the earth and all things which are in it, in the space of five days
Cardmakers God the Father forming Adam from the mud of the earth and making Eve from Adam's rib and breathing into them with the breath of life
Fullers God forbidding Adam and Eve to eat from the tree of life
Coopers Adam and Eve and the tree between them, the serpent deceiving them with fruits, God speaking to them and cursing the serpent, and the angel with a sword casting them from Paradise
°Armourers° Adam and Eve, the angel with a shovel and distaff assigning work to them
°Glovers°
Gaunters Abel and Cain offering sacrifices
Shipwrights God warning Noah to make an ark from smoothed boards
°Fishmongers°
Pessoners & Mariners Noah in the ark and his wife, Noah's three sons with their wives with various animals
Parchmenters
Bookbinders Abraham offering °Isaac,° his son, upon the altar, the servant with wood, and the angel
Hosiers Moses raising up the serpent in the desert, king Pharaoh, eight Jews wondering and waiting
Spicers °A learned man declaring the sayings of the prophets concerning the future birth of Christ,° °Mary,° the angel greeting her, Mary greeting Elizabeth
°Pewterers
Founders °Mary,° Joseph wishing to send her away, an angel speaking to them that they might go to Bethlelem°
°Pewterers
Founders °Mary,° Joseph wishing to send her away secretly, the angel speaking to them so that they go to Bethlelem°
Tilers Mary, with Joseph, the midwife, the newborn boy °lying in a manger° between the cow and the ass, the angel speaking °to the shepherds° and the players in the following pageant
Chandlers Shepherds speaking to one another, °the star in the East,° the angel announcing °the joy over the newborn boy to the shepherds°
°Goldsmiths°
Orfevers °Masons°
Goldbeaters
Moneymakers The three kings coming from the East, Herod asking them about the boy Jesus, °and the son of Herod,° and two counci°llors and a messenger,° Mary with the boy and the star above and the three kings offering gifts
°formerly° the House of St Leonard
°now Masons° Mary with the boy, Joseph, Anna, the midwife with the young doves, Simeon receiving the child into his arms, and the two sons of Simeon
Marshals Mary with the boy and Joseph fleeing into Egypt, with the angel announcing it (to Joseph)
Girdlers
Nailers °Sawyers° Herod ordering that the children be killed, four soldiers with spears, two councillors of the king, and four women weeping at the killing of their children
Spurriers
Lorimers Jesus, °the learned men, the boy° sitting in the temple in the midst of them, asking them and answering them, four Jews, Mary and Joseph seeking him and finding him in the temple
Barbers Jesus, John the Baptist baptizing him, and two angels assisting
°Vintners° Jesus, Mary the bridegroom with the bride, the steward with his servant with six jars of water when the water was turned into wine
°Smiths°
Fevers Jesus on the pinnacle of the temple, and the devil tempting him with stones, and two angels ministering, etc
Curriers Peter, James, and John, Jesus ascending the mount and transfiguring himself before them, Moses and Elijah appearing, and the voice speaking in a cloud
Ironmongers °Jesus,° Simon the leper asking Jesus to eat with him, two disciples, Mary Magdalene washing the feet of Jesus with her tears and wiping (them) with her hair
Plumbers
Pattenmakers Jesus, two apostles, the woman taken in adultery, four Jews accusing her
Pouchmakers
Bottlemakers
Capmakers
Jesus, four apostles, Lazarus in the tomb, Mary Magdalene and Martha, and two Jews wondering
°Skinners° °Vestmentmakers° Jesus on the ass with her colt, the twelve, two apostles following Jesus, six rich men and six poor men, eight boys with palm branches singing Benedictus, etc and Zacheus climbing the sycamore tree
Cutlers
Bladesmiths
Sheathers
Scalers
Bucklermakers
°Horners° Pilate, Caiaphas, two soldiers, °three Jews,° °and° Judas selling Jesus
Bakers
°Waterleaders° The paschal lamb, the Lord's supper, the twelve apostles, Jesus, girded with a linen cloth washing their feet, the paschal lamb, the institution of the sacrament of the body of Christ in the new law, the communion of the apostles
Cordwainers Pilate, Caiaphas, Annas, fourteen armed soldiers, Malchus, Peter, James, John. °Jesus,° and Judas kissing Jesus and betraying him
Bowers
Fletchers
Jesus, Annas, Caiaphas, and four Jews striking and buffeting °Jesus, Peter, the woman accusing Peter, and Malchus°
Tapiters
Couchers
Jesus, Pilate, Annas, Caiaphas, two councillors, and four Jews accusing Jesus
Litsters
Herod, two councillors, four soldiers, Jesus, and three Jews
Cooks
Waterleaders
Pilate, Annas, Caiaphas, two Jews, and Judas returning to them thirty (pieces of) silver
Tilemakers2025 expanded note: The manuscript is very damaged throughout, and especially here. This translation, replicated from REED 1979 except where noted, draws somewhat invisibly on the interventions of later scholars, particularly nineteenth-century scholars who transcribed the text before much of the damage was done. Consult the Latin text above, as well as the Endnote, to learn more about what has been damaged and replaced.
Millers
°Ropers°
°Servers° °Jesus,° Pilate, Caiaphas, Annas, six soldiers holding poles with banners and four others leading Jesus from Herod, seeking for Barabas to be released and Jesus to be crucified, and in the same place binding and whipping him, and putting a crown of thorns on his head, three soldiers casting lots upon the clothing of Jesus
Turners
Hayresters
Bollers
Shearmen
Toundours
Jesus covered with blood carrying the cross to Calvary, Simon of Cyrene, the Jews constraining him to carry the cross, Mary the mother of Jesus, then John the apostle first relating the condemnation and journey of her son °to Calvary,° Veronica wiping blood and sweat from the face of Jesus with a veil on which is imprinted the face of Jesus, and other women lamenting Jesus
Pinners
Latteners
Painters °The cross,° Jesus stretched out on it on the ground, four Jews beating (him) and dragging him with cords, and afterwards raising the cross and the body of Jesus nailed to the cross upon the mount of Calvary
Butchers
Poulters The cross, two thieves crucified, Jesus hung on the cross between them, Mary the mother of Jesus, John, Mary the mother of James, and Salome, Longinus with a spear, a slave with a sponge, Pilate, Annas, Caiaphas, the centurion, Joseph °of Arimathea° and Nicodemus taking °him° down and putting him in the tomb
°Saddlers°
Sellers °Glaziers°
Verrours
Fusters Jesus harrowing hell, twelve good and six evil spirits
Carpenters
°Joiners Cartwrights
Carvers Sawyers° °The centurion testifying to Pilate, Caiaphas and Annas °with other Jews,° the signs accompanying the death of Jesus, °Jesus rising from the tomb, four armed soldiers and the three Marys sorrowing, Pilate, Caiaphas and Annas, ° a youth clad in white sitting at the tomb, talking to the women°
Winedrawers Jesus, Mary Magdalene with spices
Brokers
Woolpackers
°Wadmen° Jesus, °Luke and Cleophas dressed as pilgrims°
Scriveners
Illuminators
°Pardoners°
Questors
Dubbers Jesus, Peter, John, James, Phillip, and the other apostles with a piece of broiled fish and a honeycomb, and Thomas the apostle touching the wounds of Christ
°Tailors°
Talliaunders Mary, John the evangelist, eleven apostles, two angels, Jesus ascending above them, and four angels bearing a cloud
Potters Mary, two angels, eleven apostles, and the Holy Spirit descending upon them, and four Jews wondering
Drapers Jesus, Mary, Gabriel with two angels, two virgins and three Jews of Mary's family, eight apostles, and two devils
°Linenweavers° Four apostles carrying the bier of Mary, and Fergus hanging upon the bier with two other Jews °and one angel°
°Woolweavers° Mary ascending with a crowd of angels, eight apostles, and Thomas, the apostle of India, preaching in the desert
°Ostlers° °Mary,° Jesus crowning her (and) singing with a crowd of angels
Mercers Jesus, Mary, twelve apostles, four angels with trumpets and four with a crown, a spear, and two whips, four good spirits and four evil spirits, and six devils
Porters 8 torches Chaloners 4 torches
Cobblers 4 torches Fullers 4 torches
Cordwainers 14 torches Girdlers torchesLook further on the following folio
Cutlers 2 torches Tailors torches
°Weavers'°
servants 4 torches And 58 citizens of the city had torches as well on Corpus Christi Day
Carpenters 6 torches
It was ordered that the Porters (and) Cobblers go before first, and then the Weavers' servants and the Cordwainers from the right. And from the other side, the Fullers, Cutlers, Girdlers, Chaloners, Carpenters, (and) Tailors. And then the honourable citizens, and afterwards the Twenty-four, the Twelve, the mayor, and the four torches of Master Thomas de Bukton.
The Proclamation of the Corpus Christi Play, to be made at the Corpus Christi Watch:
Hear ye, etc. We command, on the king's behalf, and the mayor's, and the sheriffs of this city, that no man go armed in this city with swords nor with Carlisle axes, nor any other defences, in disturbance of the king's peace and the play, or hindering of the procession of Corpus Christi; and that they leave their armour in their lodging, except knights and squires of worship that ought to have swords borne after them, on pain of forfeiture of their weapon and imprisonment of their bodies; and those men that bring forth pageants, (we command) that they play at the places that are assigned thereto, and nowhere else, on the pain of forfeiture (of fees) to be raised (according to) what is ordained (therefore), that is to say, 40 shillings. And that men of crafts, and all other men that find torches, that they come forth in array and in the manner as it and according to custom before this time, none bearing weapons (saving kee)pers of the pageants, and officers that are keepers (of the peace,) on pain of forfeiture of their franchise, and their bodies to prison. And that all types of craftsmen that bring forth their pageants (do so) in order and course, by good players, well arrayed and openly speaking, upon pain of losing 100 shillings, to be paid to the chamber, without any pardon. And that every player that shall play be ready in his pageant at a convenient time, that is to say, at the midhour between four and five of the clock in the morning (4:30 AM), and then all other pageants fast following, each one after the other as their course is, without tarrying, on the pain of making (payment) to the chamber, 6 shillings and 8 pence.York Prototype added note, Sergi 2024:This prose passage is mostly in Middle English, and so is left out of the REED 1979 translation; knowing that many online readers may simply jump to the English translation without consulting the original, I have added my own quick translation of the Middle English passage here into present-day English (I have otherwise preserved the REED 1979 translation of this record as is, with only a few minor corrections to what seem to me clearly typographical errors). Importantly, Meg Twycross, in "Forget the 4:30am Start: Recovering a Palimpsest in the York Ordo paginarum" in Medieval English Theatre 25 (2003), 98-152, reconstructs the original entry that has here been replaced by the scribal insertion extending from "And that all types of craftsmen" through to the end (which she dates roughly to the 1510s or 1520s), using UV technology. For Twycross's Middle English reconstruction, see my note to the Latin text above; here, for the reader's convenience, I'll provide a present-day English version: "And that each player who shall play should be ready in his pageant at a (???)-able time, on pain of imprisonment, the forfeiture (of fees) to be raised (according to) what has been ordained therefore".
Barkers The creation of heaven and earth
Plasterers The work of the five days
Cardmakers The formation of Adam and Eve
Walkers The prohibition of the tree of knowledge
Coupers The deceit of the devil in (the form of) a serpent
Furbers The assigning of work to Adam
Glovers Cain killing Abel
Shipwrights The building of Noah's ark
Fishmongers and Mariners Noah's ark during the flood
Parchmenters The sacrifice of Isaac by Abraham
Hosiers Pharaoh with Moses and the children of Israel
Spicers The annunciation to Mary by Gabriel
Founders Joseph wishing to send her away secretly
Tilers Bethlehem with the newborn boy
Chandlers The offering of the shepherds
°Masons Herod questioning the three kings°
Goldsmiths The offering of the three kings
St Leonard's
°now the Masons° The presentation of Christ in the temple
Marshals How Christ fled into Egypt
Girdlers Slaughter of the innocents in place of Christ
Spurriers The discovery of Christ in the temple among the learned men
Barbers The baptism of Christ by John
Taverners The marriage in Cana of Galilee
Smiths The temptation of Christ in the desert
Curriers The transfiguration of Christ
Ironmongers The feast in Simon's house
Plumbers The woman taken in adultery
Hartshorners The raising of Lazarus
Skinners Jerusalem, with citizens and children
Cutlers The selling of Christ by Judas
Bakers The supper of Christ with the disciples
Waterleaders Washing of the apostles' feet
Cordwainers The capture of Christ praying on the Mount
Bowers The mocking of Christ before Caiaphas
Tapiters The accusation of Christ before Pilate
Litsters The presentation of Christ before Herod
Cooks The contrition of Judas before the Jews
Saucemakers The hanging of Judas
Tilemakers The condemnation of Christ by Pilate
Turners, Bollers The scourging and crowning with thorns
Shearmen The leading of Christ and the manifestation to Veronica
Millers The division of the vestments of Christ
Painters The stretching out and nailing of Christ
Latteners The raising of Christ on the Mount
Butchers The death of Christ on Calvary
Saddlers The harrowing of hell
Wrights The resurrection of Christ
Winedrawers The appearance of Christ to Mary Magdalene
Woolpackers The appearance of Christ to the pilgrims
Scriveners The appearance of Christ to the apostle Thomas and to others
Tailors The ascension of Christ to heaven
Potters The descent of the Holy Spirit
Drapers The death of the blessed Mary
Masons The carrying of the body of Mary
Weavers The assumption of the blessed Mary
°Ostlers°Mayor, etc°Ostlers°
Her crowning
Mercers The last judgment
°Burton had it registered°
Potters 8 torches
Glovers 4 torches
Smiths 4 torches
°Weavers° 8 torches
Corpus christi 10 torches
William Selby for the soul of Master Thomas Bukton 4 torches
Fishers 2 torches

div.p: This 'ordo gathering' has been published in part by Drake in Eboracum, Smith in York Plays and Davies in Extracts. More recently, Martin Stevens and Margaret Dorrell Rogerson published the entire gathering in Modern Philology, fully annotated with a translation. Rather than repeat that edition, we have chosen here to represent the MS more properly in its present state of preservation. Besides the flood damage, ff 253-4 have split (or been deliberately slashed) from the bottom halfway up the folios. The breaks have been patched with paper, now discolouring and obliterating the writing underneath. Other holes in the parchment are similarly patched. We have printed what is now visible and given the readings of earlier editors in footnotes. Unless otherwise indicated, the readings in the first list are from Smith, in the second from Davies. We have not attempted to reproduce the complex variety of braces and lines connecting craft names and pageant descriptions. Although the second list (which is undated) has traditionally been assumed to be later than the first, we have preserved the gathering intact. The hands are similar, though not identical. The second list (on f 255) is in two columns.

York Prototype added note, Sergi 2025:
Beadle and Meredith append a facsimile of this record to their facsimile of the York Register (The York Play: A Facsimile of British Library MS Additional 35290, University of Leeds, 1983); therein, they describe the damage to this document in detail: "The leaves containing the Ordo paginarum and its companion pieces have suffered considerably over the course of time. Folios 253 and 254 are affected by a cut from about two-thirds of the way up f.253 and half way up f.254, which extends to the foot of both leaves. A portion of the leaf is also missing at the foot of f.253. These cuts have been repaired first by the attaching of parchment patches on the corners of the versos of both leaves, and secondly by gluing over the cut areas paper which has turned an opaque yellowy-brown. The bottom edge of f.255 has also been repaired with a parchment patch, and damage to the leaf above that has been covered with more of the same paper. This paper has also been used for a patch towards the foot of f.252v. Considerable portions of the text are thus affected by these repairs, especially on f.253v where nearly half of the page is covered by the paper patch. Furthermore the manuscript suffered in the 1892 flood when the City archives were still at the Guildhall. The level reached by the flood-water can be seen clearly on each leaf. The area above the mark left by the water is still clean and easily read, that below is stained and the writing has in many cases been washed away. This has particularly affected the original entries, and in many cases the additions and alterations alone have survived. The gradually darkening paper patches present the greatest problem, to the extent that in many cases it is no longer possible to read what is written beneath. Ultra-violet light unfortunately makes the writing underneath the paper patches even less easy to read. Most of the writing which has been washed off, however, is still legible either in bright sun or with ultra-violet light. The present state of the leaves clearly gives greater importance to the earlier transcriptions of this section of the manuscript, especially those prior to the flood of 1892, and prior to the paper repairs that followed soon after that date."

The "earlier transcriptions" thus drawn on by REED 1979 (as well as Stevens/Dorrell 1974, see above), to supply the text where floods and repairs have made the original unreadable, are the Ordo and the proclamation, are in Lucy Toulmin Smith's Introduction to her 1885 York Plays edition (Oxford: Clarendon Press) at pp. xix-xxvii and xxxiv, and in the Appendix to Francis Drake's 1736 Eboracum: Or the History and Antiquities of the City of York (London: William Bowyer) at Vol. 1, pp. xxx-xxxii. Neither of those transcriptions includes the second pageant list after the proclamation; for that, REED 1979 consults Robert Davies's 1843 Extracts from the Municipal Records of the City of York (London: J.B. Nichols and Son), at pp. 233-5. Conveniently, as of 2025 at least, all three of these early editions are available online: the Smith 1885 edition can be downloaded free of charge at Google Books, the Drake 1736 is at Eighteenth Century Collections Online, and the Davies 1843 is part of Gale's Making of Modern Law: Legal Treatises, 1800-1926 series.

Drake 1736 only provides the Latin portions of the Ordo in a then-modern English translation, which Smith 1885 rightly calls "very incorrect," but as the earliest extant witness to the damaged portions of the Ordo and proclamation it cannot be dismissed entirely. Given Smith's concern with correcting past mistranslation, and given that Stevens/Dorrell 1974 check her work fully against the extant original and find only very few corrections (at p. 58), I am inclined, as REED 1979 and Stevens/Dorrell 1974 do, to take Smith's transcription as the primary and very reliable authority on the Ordo and proclamation. Note that Smith inserts editorial punctuation for clarity, which I, following the example of Stevens and Dorrell, leave out of my transcriptions of her work here.

The full English translation included in this record, reproduced exactly from REED 1979 except where noted, incorporates those interpolated readings invisibly, smoothing out the version of the text that I suspect most readers will consult directly. But the record digitized here is anything but smooth: it is dated 1415, but is very much a palimpsest, with additions and changes made across the subsequent centuries of York Corpus Christi play production. Readers should pay close attention to the marks and notes; note too that my eREED EATS tags categorize all of the occupational collectives mentioned herein under "guilds," though some were not incorporated or recognized as such.

div.head: f 12v
div.ab:
present del king anno primo henrici vijmi Assembled determined that the king shuld haue at this his accept present a le Roy commyng to this Citie the present ensuyng ffirst in maynebrede Castes CC Also in wyne of Rosse colour A Tone In gret fatt oxen vj In gret and fatt Weders I And ouer this þat the Maier and Aldermen cled in Colour of violet in greyne the xxiiij cled in clothing colour of violet Murrey the Communaltie in Gounes of Rede shall waite on the king on horse at Bilburghcrosse on this half after that at two of the saide Aldermen and the two Sheriffes haue mett with his grace at Tadcastre brige the extremities of the boundes of this fraunches And Also that in consideracion of that at the Kinges highnesse Remembering the pouertie decay and Ruyn of this Citie shewid vnto hyme by the moost Reuerend fader in god Tharchbishop of york Richard york and Robert Hancok late being at his parliament and other is content to haue no money of the same Citie as by meyne of Reward like as other Kinges of England haith be accustomed to haue heire before of the same Citie at þer first and next commyng to the forsaide Citie and other Cities of his Realme wol that some conuenyent shew be had ayenst the kinges saide Commyng by the Counsell of some which can devise the same wherby his highnesse may the rather be movid to toMS to to think that the said maier Aldermen Sheriffes and other inhabitances heyr be gladdid and loifull of the same his commyng as thei haue be in tymes past of seing commyng of other kinges yer souerain lord
Assembled concludid with Sir Henrie Hudsone prest that he shuld haue the conueance of the making and directing of the shew to be maide ayenst the kinges next commyng heder which the said henrie haith vndertake to do to the worship of the Citie heyre And for the same shew he shall haue in Rewarde of the saide Citie ouer thexpenses tobe maide in that partie And Rewardes tobe yeven to other persones to be occupied about the same tobe borne by the forsaid Citie / five marces in money with some conuenient thing to be yeuen at the pleasure of the said Maier vnto the Church of Spofford wher the said Sir Henrie is parich prest haueing Cure of the soules of the pariching yerIn
It is concludit by the Maier his breder Aldermen and other of the Common Counesell of the Citie that thei being in gude hope to fynd the king more gracious soueraine lord vnto the forsaide Citie by the mediacion of the most Reuerend fadre in godd tharchbisshop of york and other lordes spirituall and temporall of his moost noble Counesaill shewing theime and all thinbitances thinbitancesbrevigraph omitted for thinhabitances yerof gretely gladdit and Ioyed of the Commyng of his moost Riall persone with other his nobles vnto the saide Citie haue ordeigned and prepared to Receyue the kinges grace in forme felowing that is to saie ffirst Wher the two sheriffes of the saide Citie for the tyme being with xx horses haith be accustumed to yeue yer attandance of kinges herbefor resorting vnto the Citie at Tadcastre brige being thextremitie of yer fraunches It is now concludid that not oonly the saide two sheriffes bot aswell two of the Aldermen accumpaned with xl horsses shall yer wait on his grace Secundly where the Maire and Aldermen cled in long gownys of skarlet and other of the Couneseil accumpanyd with thinhabitances of the Citie haue be accustumed to wait of kinges in lykwise commyng to the Citie on horse bak aboute two miles fro the Citie thei be determined that the saide Maier And Aldermen in like clothing of skarlet the Comon Couneseill and clerc in violet Chambrelayns in murray and many of thinhabitances in Rede on horse bak shall wait on the king at Bilburgh crose about v miles fro the Citie and other thinhabitaunces which may not ride or be of power to haue rede gownes to yeue yer attendance on foote betwixt dringhowsis and the Citie beside a certaine nowmbre of Childrine as shalbe gaddard togiddre aboute saint Iames Chappell calling loyfully king henrie after the maner of Children iij Thirdly at the entre of the Citie and first bar of the same shalbe craftelye conceyvid a place in maner of A heven of grete Ioy and Anglicall Armony vnder the heven shalbe a world desolaite full of treys and floures In the which shall spryng vp A rioall rich rede rose convaide by viace vnto the which Rose shall appeyre an other Rich white rose vnto whome so being to gedre all other floures shall lowte and evidently yeue suffrantie shewing the Rose tobe principall of all floures as witnesh Barthilmow And yerypon shall come fro A cloude A crowne Couering the Roses after the which shall appeir A Citie with Citisyns with the begynner of the same callid Ebrauk which shall salute the king with wordes felowing in prose and yervpon present vnto the king the keys of the Citie being thenheritaunce of the saide Ebrauk yelding his title and his Crowne vnto the king as moost glad of hym above al other
Ebrauke
Most Reuerend rightwose regent of this Rigalitie Whos primatiue patrone I peyre to your presence Ebrauuk of britane I sitt nat this Citie ffor A place to my pleasour of moost prehemynence Hervnto I recoursid for moost conuenience In comforthing that by cource of liniall succession Myne heires this my Citie shuld haue in possession
Of Right I was regent and rewlid this rigion I subdewid fraunce and led in my legence To you henrie I submitt my Citie key and Croune To reuyll and redresse your dew to defence Neuer to this Citie to presume ne pretence Bot holy I graunt it to your gouernaunce as A principall parcell of your inheritaunce
Please it I besuch you for my remembrance Seth that l am prematiue of your progenie Shew your grace to this Citie with such Abounedance As the reame may recouer in to prosperitie And also of your grace gyve not your ee oonely to this Citie of insufficience Bot graciously consider yerwith and diligence
It is knawne in trueth of grete experience ffor your blode this Citie made neuer degression As recordith by the grete hurt for blode of your excellence Wherfor the rather I pray for compassion And to mynd how this Citie of old and pure affeccion Gladdith and Inioith your high grace and commyng With oon concent knowing you yer sufferaine and king
ffourtly the king Commyng vp the stretes shallse the same furnishede with clothis of the best which may begottyn within the Citie for the honourment of the same and at his entrie vnto vuse brigge in theend of the streetes of Skeldargate and Northstrete becauce no gappes shall appeir shall yerbe Clothes hangid and A conuenient thing diuisid wherby if the weder be fair of the lordes before and other ne before the king schall Rayne Rose water ffiftly shalbe on the hight of ousebrigge A Rioall Treyne and yerin sodainely appering set togidder in Counsail sex kinges Crouned betokining the sex henries which after the sight had of the king with certaine conuenient laisour avisidly shall commyt A ceptour vnto Salamon cledd as king which salamon shall yervpon taking that Ceptour and saying the wordes felowing vnto the king in prose yelde vnto him the saide Ceptour in tokining that in hym is wisdome and Iustice
Salomon
Most prudent prince of pruved prevision Their primordiall princes of this principalitie Haith preparate your reame the vijth by succession Remitting reame als right to your Rialtie Their ar kinges condigne of your consanguinitie ffull riall and rightwose in rewle of yer regence And ful lordly thai execute the lawes of yer legence
Seth that god moost glorius eternall sapience Did insence me salomon of his effluent grace Wherfore I am takin as patrone of prudence To discuse vpin conscience ich iudiciall cace Revolving how with sapience ye haue spent your space To the tyme of this your misteriusly obteyning as moost worthi your right not regosly
Now reane ye reule ye your reame rightwosly By politike prouidence as god haith in dewid To you sufferaunce in sapience submitting me vmbly your sage savour sothfastnese haith so be shewid In ich Iudiciall right this reame to be renewid ye be avisid most worthi by graciouse affluence Submitting to your sufferaunt my septour of sapience
vj Sextly shal appere in thend of A strete loning on the syde of ousegate passing into Conyngstrete shalbe A shew and fro the same shall come hailestones tobe maid by viace falling on the lordes and other commyng ne before the King hailestones to be made by craftes of cumfettes vij Sevently shalbe at the Common Hall A Castell appeiring of grete force wherin Dauid as the moost principall shall appeir and he shall with wordes felowing yeld vnto the king A swerd of his victorie yerer shalbe in that Castell Citisyns which after A sight of the king and remembrance of hyme with gude countenaunce shall appeir in clothing of white and greyne shewing yer trueth and hertly affeccion vnto the kinge
Dauid
Most prepotent prince of power Imperiall Redowtid in ich region of Cristes affiance your actes victorious be notid principall In maner more noble then Charlis of fraunce Seth god so disposith of his preordiniance And right so yeue me might to devyne goodly I dauid submitt to you my swerd of victorie
When I reynid in ludie I know and testify That Ebraunce the noble which subdewid ffraunce In memorie of his triumph this Citie did edify That the name of his noble shuld haue continuance I witnesh that this Citie without variaunce Was neuer deflorid be force in violence Wherfore I haue chosyn it for my place to your presence
Submitting it with thafforce and trueth to your excellence Beseching your highnese ye more for myne instance To this your inheritance tak gracious complacence seth yat it is your Citie not filid with dissavaunce Trew and bold to your blode not dreding perturbance Which causid moost this citie tobe desolate Now reviving in comforth to attaine your asstate
Eghtly shalbe at thend of Swynegale loning of staynegate our lady commyng frome hevin and welcome the king in wordes felowing and yervpon ascend ayene into heven wit angell sang and yer schall it snaw by craft tobe made of waffrons in maner of Snaw
Oure lady
Henrie seth my sone as thi sufferayne haith the sembly assynyd Of his grace tobe gouerner for his people prorotection ffull specially that thine heier of petie be declinid I pray the seth thi people haith me mich in affeccion My Son and my soveraine in whome is eleccion Singulerly this Citie haith honourd humbely And maide me yer meane withoutin obieccion In hope of yer help to haue it holy What I axk of his grete grace he grantith it gudely As a beame of all bevtes benyngne The his knyght he haith callid victoriously To convoce and concord this his contrie condigne I pray in this space ffor this Citie a place of my pleasing And haue you no drede nor no dowting Continuall heir in this reynyng. I shall sew to my sone to send you his grace
(4 October) Assembled acceptid and admittid Robert Comgilton one of the waites of this Citie tobe in the Roume of Robert sheyne being in so grete age and soo decrepid that he no may forther attend toccupacion of waite forsaide In consideracion wherof and of the long continued seruice that he haith done in the saide Roume by the space of .xl. yeres and more It is determined that the saide Robert Sheyne yerely during his life And whils the said Robert Comgilton shalbe here waite shalhaue in name of a pension of the same Robert Comgilton thertene shelinges and for four penys tobe payde wharterly without deley and forther that the saide Robert Sheyne shuld haue in his reliefe during his life a house of the Commons with charge of Reparacion without eny other forme paying for the same
